The village is not yet connected to the power and the water grids but she expect this to be done soon. When her loan will be disbursed, T. Eorn will purchase raw materials and hire two people for three weeks, until the works are completed.

“This new house is a real chance for the 7 of us”, she said, “because living outside the city is good for our health and safer for our children”.

loans.use: Building a new house for his family

loans.name: Rosidah

texts.en:
R. is 32 years old, and is married with two children, both girls aged 15 and 10. The eldest is attending senior high school, while the younger one is in elementary school. Her husband, Salim, does not have a fixed job, so he does odd jobs, carrying goods and off-loading trucks when he can.

R. buys waste material like plastic cups, plastic bottles, cardboard and paper from her neighbors and other houses in the village. Her husband uses a cart to collect scrap metal and other waste material. Households do not just give away waste material, because there is demand and therefore economic value in recycling. So the more working capital they have, the more scrap they can collect and recycle. Their own working capital is limited, at around $250. Having heard from her friends about MBK, R. has now applied to MBK to add to her working capital. Since this is the first time, R. can only borrow a maximum of $75 from MBK.

The recycling business consists of the following chain. R. and her husband are the first link in this chair, buying waste and scrap materials from households, sorting and cleaning them, before selling them to an intermediate dealer. This dealer comes around in a small truck, collects the sorted-out material and takes it to the warehouse dealer. There, the different materials are weighed in front of R.’s husband, who then gets paid by the intermediate dealer. The warehouse dealer in turn sends the waste material to various processing factories, which turn produce clean and reusable recycled paper, cardboard and plastic recycled raw materials. Waste recycling undertaken by R. and her husband thus helps clean the environment by reusing waste material which otherwise would go to the landfills.

loans.use: Purchase waste material

loans.name: Aniva

texts.en: Aniva is fifty-four years of age and has six children.  Aniva believs that her small business really helps her raise her family’s standard of living.  She is also very confident of her abilities to run the business, especially since she has support from her family and friends, and they believe in her enterprise.  She started off with only one product – selling baked fish in her local village; but with previous SPBD loans, she explored adding a second product, baked chicken.  Since she started, she feels that her customer base has grown a lot and she feels there is more growth possible if she is able to expand her supply and product line.  Aniva admits to working very hard to make this business a success and is proud of her efforts.  She is confident that she is able to provide the best quality goods with the lowest prices in the village.  Aniva will use the loan funds to purchase larger supplies of fish and chicken as well as some basic baking supplies.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and baking supplies

texts.en: Mrs. H. is 49 years old, and her husband is 50. They have three children, ages 19 to 26 who all have left the house. They live in Nghe An, a rural province in the upper center of Vietnam. Mrs. H. raises pigs and washes dishes for the next door restaurant; her husband fixes bicycles. She wants to buy more breeding pigs to increase her income. A breeding pig will give birth to piglets after three months and can do that twice a year. Mrs. H. earns $25.00 per month with dishwashing and the pig raising gives her an extra $50.00 per month.

loans.use: to buy more breeding pigs

loans.name: Amadu Bamkolo

texts.en: Amadu Bamkolo K. sells fuel and lubricant in the village of Fadugu in Sierra Leone.  He is forty-eight years old, married with three teenage children.  With his previous loan, Amadu increased his stock and used the profit to diversify his business.  He purchased a goat and sheep and he plans to establish animal husbandry that will include cows.  He is requesting a loan of $175 to increase his fuel business and to begin his dream.

loans.use: Increase fuel business for future diversification of the business.

loans.name: Hairiniso

texts.ru:
Hairiniso, 55, has been in business for a few years. She is married and has 4 children. Her husband works for the state. Hairiniso’s older son and daughter help her in business. Hairiniso buys her inventory from a wholesaler in Istaravshan. Hairiniso increased the sales volume a few times over the 3 years that she has been a MicroInvest client. She plans to invest this loan into ongoing expansion of her business.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хайринисо 55 лет, но, несмотря на свой возраст, она уже несколько лет занимается бизнесом. Хайринисо замужем и у нее 4 детей. Муж тоже работает на государственной службе. В бизнесе ей помогают старшие сын и дочь. За товаром она ездит на оптовый рынок г. Истаравшан. Клиентом Микроинвест является 3 года. за этот период обороты ее бизнеса возросли в несколько раз. Хайринисо планирует получить новый займ на дальнейшее расширение своего бизнеса.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Omua

texts.en: Mrs. Omua O. is a fashion designer by profession. She is 32 years old, married with 2 children, and she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has been in this business since 2002. She requests a loan of $475 to enable her buy more cloth and tailoring material to make clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more cloth and tailoring material

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah S. wants to set up her own bakery. She is requesting a loan to purchase baking supplies. In addition, she also wants to buy a fridge with the loan.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To set up a bakery

loans.name: Anong

texts.en: Anong, 47, is the mother of a child aged 22; her husband had passed away a long time ago. To provide for her family's needs, she has been selling vegetables door-to-door around the villages and earns $10 a day. She is a member of MBK and asks for a loan of $75 to buy goods to sell. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Buy more goods

loans.name: Ligia

texts.es:
Señora Ligia is a member of the communal bank Las Perlas de Pucallpa, located on Avenue Sáenz Peña in the district of Calleria in Ucayali. Ligia is 51 years old and a mother of three daughters. With her first loan of 300 Soles she decided to invest in clothing sales.

Presently she continues with the clothing business, buts she also sells OmniLife products. Since her children are already independent and she is separated, she is dedicated to the business for which she must go out a lot to offer products and gain more earnings.

With the loan of 1000 Soles, which she will pay back in five months, she will invest in purchasing clothes and also buying products of OmniLife.

Ligia is a mother who found out how to help her daughters move ahead in life, and although in difficult moments she had to fight, she never surrendered. Now her daughters support her and she feels peaceful and good about her self.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

La señora Ligia pertenece al banco comunal Las Perlas de Pucallpa, ubicado en la Av. Sáenz Peña N° 469, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Ligia tiene 51 años y es madre de 3 hijas. Con su primer préstamo de S/ 300 decidió invertir en la venta de ropas.

En la actualidad continúa con el negocio de ropa, pero también vende productos omnilife. Como sus hijos ya son independientes y ella es separada se dedica a los negocios para lo cual tiene que salir mucho para ofrecer y tener más ganancias.

Con el préstamo de S/ 1,000 soles, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de ropa y también invertirá en la compra de productos omnilife.

Ligia es una madre que supo sacar adelante a sus hijas y aún en los momentos más difíciles que tuvo que atravesar nunca sé rindió y ahora sus hijas la apoyan y se siente más tranquila y bien consigo misma.

loans.use: Buy clothing

loans.name: Juliet Nakamatte’S Group

texts.en:
Juliet, age 30, is the leader of this five-person group. This is the group’s first loan with MCDT. Juliet is married with four children. All of her children are in school, except for her youngest. Her husband sells used refrigerators.

Juliet has a business selling poultry and pigs. She plans to use the loan to buy more chickens and increase her feed stock. If things go well, she would like to expand her living space and increase the size of her business. She also hopes that the profits from her business will be enough to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy chickens and feed

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is 41 years old, and she is the mother of five children, all of whom are in school. She has been selling grocery products for two years, and she has recently added certain products such as fresh pineapples, plantains, and cocoyams to her business's inventory. While she sells her foodstuffs in the local city where she is able to generate considerable sales, she has to buy her grocery products from Accra and the foodstuffs from another nearby village.

As such, Dora is seeking a loan to buy more bags of pineapple, sacks of plantains, and cocoyams, as well as other groceries such as canned tomatoes, canned fish, soap, and evaporated milk.

She is a member of the group called “Eye Yehowa” (meaning, "it is God"). Group members exert positive peer pressure on each other as social collateral to encourage the group members to promptly repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing additional food and grocery products (e.g., pineapple, cocoyams, and plantains).

loans.name: Mabira Development Group

texts.en:
Muwanga N. is the chairperson of Mabira Development Group, a group that has been together for 10 years. She has a retail shop business selling soda, juice and mineral water in Najjembe, located in the middle of Mabira forest on the Kampala - Jinja road. It is also a common place for selling roasted meat, chicken, yellow bananas and gonja to passengers in moving vehicles. She employs a total of five boys and girls to do the running around with cold water and juice to passengers in the stopping vehicles. The profits they make are shared with her as their daily wage; meaning the more they sell, the more they earn. Muwanga is a married woman with eight children of whom four are still in school. She takes care of one of her sick sister’s children, paying for school fees in a boarding section, plus one grandchild not yet in school.

Muwanga needs a loan to buy more soda, mineral water and juice for her shop. Her dream is to own a much bigger shop with more soda, mineral water and juice plus other goods like sugar, tea leaves and other foodstuffs to accompany her drinks.

Muwanga will share this loan with the members of her group. The group is really thankful to Kiva for giving them this opportunity.

loans.use: To buy more soda, mineral water and juice for her shop.

loans.name: Martha Isabel

texts.es:
Martha Isabel C. works very hard running a tailor's shop from her home in the county of La Paz Centro in the city of Leon. She has been doing this for 20 long years and throughout this time she has managed to gather a lot of experience in her field.

She is a single mother with a young son that she must support. Her multiple efforts are all so that she can feed him and pay for his education. Now she is asking for a loan so that she can buy equipment for her work such as needles, thread, material and more. This is why she is looking for financing from Ceprodel; so that she can get the necessary credit and therefore continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

En el municipio de La Paz Centro de la ciudad de León, la señora Martha Isabel C. se dedica a trabajar en el negocio de sastrería el cual atiende muy esforzadamente en su casa de habitación. SE dedica a este negocio desde hace 20 largos años y a través de este tiempo ha logrado alcanzar una basta experiencia en su ramo.

Es madre soltera y con un pequeño hijo con el deber de mantener. Sus múltiples esfuerzos los realiza para brindarle el alimento a su pequeño y así poder continuar con sus estudios. Hoy en día solicita un crédito para la compra de sus materiales de trabajo como lo es hilos, agujas, telas y mas. Por esto busca el financiamiento en Ceprodel para obtener el crédito necesario y de esta manera continuar en su negocio.

loans.use: To buy materials to work with/Compra de materiales para trabajo

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
Nancy is a hard-working woman who spends her time selling candy and drinks in a small store that she built years ago. This business has helped her cover living expenses for her four children. Nancy puts a lot into her store, because she knows that if she works hard she can turn it into a prosperous business. For this reason she hopes to start improving it by supplying new merchandise and a diverse set of products that are difficult to find in the region but can satisfy her clients' needs. Nancy believes that if she can supply these products, her business will attract more visits from her neighbors. Nancy needs 1500 soles to complete the quality improvements, and she promises to be punctual and responsible in her repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

Nancy es una mujer emprendedora que trabaja en la venta de dulces y de bebidas en la pequeña tienda que instaló hace un par de años. Dicho negocio le ayuda a solventar los gastos de sus cuatro hijos.Ella está muy entregada a su tienda, porque sabe que si se esfuerza más podrá hacer de él un negocio muy prospero, por ello, desea empezar a mejorarlo desde ya, surtirlo con nueva mercadería y diversos productos que sean difíciles de encontrar en la zona para poder satisfacer la necesidad de sus clientes, así propiciar la mayor concurrencia de sus vecinos a su bodega.La suma que requiere para ello es de 1500 soles, que espera que usted, pueda brindarle en calidad de préstamo y con la promesa de ser puntual y responsable en sus pagos.

loans.use: Buy new, unique merchandise for her store

loans.name: Aziz

texts.en:
C. Aziz is a widower. He is a businessman of 27 who deals in a variety of merchandise: mirrors, needles, thread, soap, shampoo, toothbrushes and other small items. He sells his merchandise on both a retail and a wholesale basis. His business is located in the local market.

His sister who is pictured in the photo helps Aziz with the business. Aziz is looking after two dependant children: a girl aged 7 and a boy of 5. He has been able to meet the needs of the children using the income from his business but unfortunately this leaves him with almost no savings available as capital for investment.

Aziz is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) to expand his business. When this is achieved, he believes he will be able to save money to buy a plot of land where he can construct a house. This loan will be repaid in 3 months. Aziz thanks all for their support and promises to manage the loan without any violations.

loans.use: Purchasing goods in order to enlarge his inventory

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is forty-six year old Debora M. from Mwanza. She is married with seven children, between the ages of eight and thirty-five. Debora has been running a grocery business since 2005. Her business is selling soda, biscuits, tea leaves, sugar, and flour. She works at the business for sixteen hours per day, six days per week. Debora currently earns about US$ 200 from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$ 450 in order to buy maize flour, soda, rice, and wheat flour. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of of her stock. Debora thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, soda, rice, and wheat flour

loans.name: Marivel

texts.es:
La señora Marivel, socia del Banco Comunal “Las Victorias”, vive en el departamento de San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Se dedica a la reparación y venta repuestos para artefactos, sobre todo brinda mantenimiento de computadoras. El negocio está ubicado en el  Jr. La Merced Nº 931,  lugar donde a diario acuden sus clientes que cada día aumentan por la calidad de su trabajo y los repuestos que oferta.

Con este crédito de S/.1,500, el cual será cancelado en en 6 meses, comprará repuestos y accesorios diversos, los cuales necesita en la realización de sus trabajos, eso da confianza y seguridad a sus servicio y sobre todo la satisfacción de sus clientes, que es lo más importante para ella.   

La señora Marivel tiene 35 años de edad, vive con su esposo y con sus 02 hijos, quienes son su motor para seguir trabajando y para darles un futuro mejor. Es una mujer muy optimista que anhela más adelante ampliar y arreglar su local.
texts.en:
Marivel, a member of the Las Victorias community bank, lives in Juanjuí, in the Mariscal Cáceres province of San Martín region. She devotes her time to the repair and sale of appliance spare parts, especially for computer maintenance. Her shop is located at number 931 in the neighborhood of La Merced, a place to which an ever-increasing number of customers turn each day due to the quality of the workmanship and the parts available. With this six-month loan of $500 (1500 nuevos soles), she will purchase parts and various accessories needed for completing the jobs. It will inspire confidence in the service they provide and most importantly customer satisfaction, which is of paramount importance to her. Marivel is 35 years old, and lives with her husband and two children, who are the impetus that drives her to continue working to give them a better tomorrow. She is a very optimistic woman who in the future longs to expand and refurbish her business premises.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of parts and a variety of accessories

loans.name: Joseph Ekow

texts.en: Joseph Ekow G. sells hardware and electrical products at Kormantse near Cape Coast. Joseph Ekow has received a junior high education.  He is married and has 3 children. His wife is a trader. Joseph Ekow has been selling hardware and electrical products since 2004. He is responsible for paying utility bills and school fees. His loan will be used to buy more hardware and electrical products for resale to his ever increasing customer base. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to plough back into the growing business.

loans.use: His loan will be used to buy more hardware and electrical products for resale to his ever increasing costumers.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Rin C. R. is married and has three children, all between 2 and 16 years old. The family lives in the Tboung Khmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. 
Rin C. R. earns income selling various kinds of groceR. products, while her husband, Lai Phet, is a broker, buying rice crops from the growers and reselling them to vendors at a market. In a typical month, Rin C. R.'s family spends around US$41 on food and US$10 on their two schooling-age children's tuition. To make extra income for the household, Rin C. R. and her husband are now asking for a loan to be able to purchase a couple of pigs for breeding, learning from their neighbors who are already engaged in this type of business.

loans.use: Purchase of pigs for breeding

loans.name: Cecilia Madeleine

texts.en:
Cecilia Madeleine M. Rodriguez is forty years old.  She lives with her husband and her two children in the city of Pucallpa, Peru.  Cecilia’s business is growing and selling plants.  Cecilia is a member of the Las Brisas communal bank and has worked with her group for two years.

Cecilia uses her loans to purchase plant food, pesticides, soil, seeds, seedlings and other plant growing materials.  She is currently requesting a Kiva loan of 2,500 Nuevo Soles to purchase more plants, chemicals and fertilizers.  She will also use the money to rent tools to help her cultivate her plants.  Cecilia appreciates the opportunity to work with more capital and appreciates your support.

loans.use: To purchase more plants, chemicals and fertilizers.

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina M. is twenty-seven years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all of whom are girls. She says all her daughters are now in basic school. Augustina’s husband is a trader. He trades in second-hand gadgets such as television sets, radios, fridges, etc. She lives with her children and husband in her in-laws' house in Offinso in the Ashanti Region of Ghana.

Augustina works very hard to support her husband in providing for the family. She is a food vendor. She cooks rice with stew. Augustina sells on a table top in the compound of the local community school. She buys bags of rice from Kumasi. She has been in business for five years. She wants to buy bags of rice on a large scale so that she can cut down on costs, such as frequent trips to procure goods. It is her dream to help her husband so that they can put up their own structure.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice in bulk, which she'll cook with stew

loans.name: Nathaly

texts.es: Nathaly tiene 19 años y vive en casa de sus padres. Se dedica en la atención de su puesto de ventas desde hace un año, empezó desde que era muy joven ayudando a su mamá, ahora administra su propio negocio aplicando lo que aprendió en los pasados años. Nathaly atiende durante todo el día, lo que vende son artículos de ferretería, todo lo concerniente para instalaciones eléctricas, llaves, candados entre otros. Para Nathaly este negocio es rentable a pesar de que existan épocas del año en las ventas son bajas, sin embargo siempre le deja ganancias. Ahora tiene planes de aumentar su mercadería para tener artículos más diversos y obtener otro puesto de venta. Es la primera vez que Nathaly tiene un préstamo con MFP, ella integra su banco comunal con muchas expectativas positivas, ya que escuchó recomendaciones favorables de lo que es trabajar en un banco comunal. El dinero que solicita es para comprar grandes cantidades de focos, fluorescentes, conectores eléctricos, etc.
texts.en:
Nathaly is 19 and lives with her parents. For a year she has worked attending a sales location, she started when she was very young helping her mother, now she manages her own business and applies to it what she has learned over the years. Nathaly works all day, what she sells are hardware products, anything related to electric installations, keys, locks, among others. For Nathaly this business is profitable in spite of parts of the year in which sales are low; however there have always been earnings. She now has plans to increase merchandise and have a large variety of products as well as having another sales location. This is the first time that Nathaly gets a loan with MFP, she forms part of the community bank with positive expectations, because she heard good references about how it is to work in a community bank. The money requested is to purchase large quantities of bulbs, lights, electric connectors, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Sofia Burt, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase amount and variety of merchandise

loans.name: Shirjana

texts.en:
Shirjana M. is the tailor in the village of Thecho. She took six months of training for her tailoring work. She especially prefers to make the new style dresses such as the kurta-sulwar and blouse which are very popular among Nepalese girls and women. She is requesting Rs 10000.00 for her first loan to purchase raw materials for her tailoring work such as clothes, cutting machines etc.

Mrs. Shirjana M. lives in a single-family house with her husband and three sons. Her husband, Mr. Dev Bahadur, works in a carpet factory. Her older and middle sons are now studying in grades seven and four. Her younger son is just two years old.

She uses her income to fulfill the needs of her family. She wants to spend her income to provide a good education for all her sons.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Condrada

texts.en:
Condrada M. is a 57 yearold mother of four. She is married to a farmer who works a small parcel of land inherited from his parents. She raises pigs and barters for rice every harvest season. She trades soft drinks and bread for rice (palay) then resells to support her husband’s income. This livelihood of hers started 33 years ago, but improving the family's living conditions remains impossible.

Condrada applied for this loan to finance fertilizers and insecticides and to buy one piglet. She wants to buy these items in advance in order to get a lesser price, and to avoid borrowing money from her neighbor during planting season. When she borrows from her neighbor, she usually pays back in rice grains after harvest which is very disadvantageous to her. Condrada hopes that through her loan, she and her husband can save their harvest and get a better price at market. She wants to help support her grand children's education, buy another rice field, and build a better house for the family.

loans.use: Buy fertlizer and insecticides and one piglet.

loans.name: Atoullo

texts.en:
K. Atoullo is a 29-year-old man who is married and has two children. Atoullo’s goals are to grow in his personal life and in his business. His wish is to offer better service to his customers. His dream is that God continues to provide him with more life so that he can get ahead and fulfill his goals.

He is a taxi driver and travels the streets of Dushanbe City in search of customers. He has owned his business for two years. 

Today, Atoullo is planning to replace the fuel supply system of his taxi with one using liquified gas, as the gas is cheaper than petrol (gasoline). For this purpose he wants to borrow $800.

He sincerely thanks Kiva and all its lenders for making this help possible.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International
Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium B.C. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History
Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit:  www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy a kapron gas-cylinder for the taxi's fuel supply system

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Graciela es socia del Bancomunal Fuerza y Poder.
Graciela trabaja con su esposo él es chofer y ella cobra, siempre alquilaban un carro para trabajar, un amigo le ofreció vender una couster de segunda con los ahorros que tenían y con los prestamos lograron comprarla, su esposo es chofer de su couster y ella cobra.  
Graciela necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles, para el arreglo de su couster.  
Desde que Graciela esta en Finca, puede cubrir sus gastos, ya no corre a los prestamistas que le cobraban 20% de interés, ella se siente más tranquila encuentra un apoyo.  
El sueño de Graciela es comprarse otro carro pero a gas.
texts.en:
Graciela is a member of the Fuerza y Poder (“Strength and Power”) cooperative bank. Graciela works with her husband, who is a driver, and she does the billing/charges. They always rented a car to work, and a friend offered to sell them a used coaster (a small type of bus). With their savings and some loans, they were able to buy it. Her husband drives the coaster, and she handles the charges. Gabriela needs a loan of 1000 soles to make repairs to the coaster. Since Graciela started with Finca, she is able to cover her expenses and doesn’t have to go to loan sharks that charge her 20% interest. She feels more at peace now that she has found some support. Graciela’s dream is to buy herself another vehicle, but one that runs on gas.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Graciela needs a loan of 1000 soles to make repairs to her coaster bus.

loans.name: Chak

texts.en: Chak P. is a 36-year-old widowed mother of three children who are still young and enrolled in school. She makes a living working as a garment worker in the garment industry in Phnom Penh City. Additionally, she also cultivates a rice crop during the farming season. The rice-farming season is coming and Chak P. is lacking fertilizer to grow a rice crop. Thus, she is applying for a loan to purchase fertilizers for her farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Kape

texts.en: Kape E. is currently in the business of selling beer and is requesting a loan to purchase more crates of beer to sell. Kape is 45 years old and is married to a husband who is a driver. She has seven children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To purchase more beer to sell

loans.name: Aminu

texts.en:
Aminu is married and is the mother of three children and all her children are currently in school. They live at Sefwi in the western region of Ghana. Aminu is a very hardworking Moslem who does not relax when it comes to work. For that reason, most of her age group admire her so much.

Currently Aminu is a corn-dough seller. She buys maize from the farmers which she then mills to obtain the corn dough. Corn dough is used to prepare so many local dishes like banku (served with hot pepper or soup), maize porridge, kenkey (served with hot pepper and fried fish), etc. 

Amina has two years experience in her business. She is requesting the loan to buy bags of maize to use to prepare the corn dough. She would be grateful for your assistance. She belongs to the village bank “Nyame Bekyere” which literaly means “God Provides”.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Basilia

texts.es: Basilia tiene 32 años, es una madre muy trabajadora y responsable, vive en su propia casa junto a su esposo Miguel de 35 años y su hija Elena de 8 años, a quienes desea darles una vida mejor. La jornada de Basilia comienza a las 6 de la mañana, cuando abre su tienda de abarrotes y se alista para empezar a vender sus productos, su tienda está ubicada en el barrio la Rinconada (barrio importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), donde atiende todo el día hasta a las 9 de la noche, cuando cierra su puesto sabiendo que al día siguiente le espera otra larga jornada de trabajo. Lo que más le gusta de su negocio es conversar con sus clientes, así hace más amenas sus largas jornadas de trabajo, lleva 4 años realizando esta actividad y lo que menos le gusta es tener que permanecer todo el día en su tienda, aun así sabe que su sacrificio no es en vano. Para un futuro cercano espera tener una tienda más grande donde pueda vender productos más variados. Este es el primer préstamo de Basilia con MFP y sabe que tiene que pagar sus cuotas a tiempo. En su banco comunal es muy alegre y siempre está al tanto de todos los acuerdos que tienen entre socias. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados, comprará más productos para su tienda y así podrá ofrecer a sus clientes un mejor stock.
texts.en:
Basilia is 32 years old and is a hard-working and responsible woman. She lives in her own house with her husband Miguel, who is 35 years old, and their daughter Elena, who is 8 years old. Basilia wants to give them a better life. The hard-working Basilia wakes up at 6 in the morning, when she opens her grocery store and prepares to begin selling her products. Her store is located in the neighborhood of La Rinconada, which is an important neighborhood in the city of Juliaca. She works at her grocery store all day, until 9 at night, when she closes the store, knowing that the next day will bring another long work-day. What she likes most about her business is talking with her clients; this makes the long days more pleasant. She has spent 4 years working in her business. What she likes least is having to spend all day in her store, even though she knows that her sacrifice is not in vain. In the near future, she hopes to have a larger store, where she can sell more varied products. This is her first loan with MFP, and she knows that she has to pay her installments on time. In her community bank, she is very happy and is always up to date with the agreements that exist among the members. With the 1000 soles that she is requesting, she will buy more products for her store and will be able to offer more items to her clients.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To increase her merchandise

loans.name: Celenia

texts.en:
Celenia, at the age of forty-six, is a woman full of dreams that remain unrealized due to unceasing hardships prevalent in the country. She hopes that someday she can achieve her goals and desires in life through her perseverance in her business. Celenia also believes that Kiva lenders will grant her loan request of PHP 7,000 for business capital. 

Celenia is married to Romeo, who works as a farmer in the village of Santos Quezon, Isabela. They are blessed with three children: Romeo, Nino Roeland and Rocel Ann Mae. With her general store business, Celenia is able to help her husband support the education of their children and provide their daily needs. Learning about Kiva loans is an opportunity, says Celenia, because she will be able to generate additional capital for her business to grow.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Marilou

texts.en:
Marilou would like to request a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 5,000. This amount is very helpful in maintaining the rice and corn thresher that farmers rent during harvest season. She is living in the small village of Anguapan, Tumauini, Isabela. 

Marilou also aspires to have a livestock business in order to have an additional source of income which, will be beneficial also for the sustenance of the agricultural business. Her plan with the loan includes purchasing piglets to fatten. Marilou is married to Wilfredo, the father of her five children. One of her five children is studying and she hopes to send her to college.

loans.use: To maintain farm equipment, and to purchase pigs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: the repair of his car (taxi)

loans.name: Mandador Group

texts.en:
Nancy T. is married and has three children whose ages range between 5 and 10 years. The older two attend school, with the elder in the seventh grade. For about two years, Nancy has been involved in the sale of dry goods such as sugar, batteries, candles, and salt. She has been challenged by family troubles as well as by financial problems, but is successful in her business and attracts her customers by good service and also by offering good and reasonable prices.

She hopes to improve her business to the point of establishing a shop. Her goal is to better support her children.

loans.use: To buy dry goods such as sugar, batteries, candles, and salt for sale

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia is already thirty-eight years old and is happily married to Nel, who is forty years old. They are engaged in cultivating their own farm located in their village. They are blessed with three children: Violeta, their eldest, is now twenty-two years old and has just finished high school; next to her is Russel, thirteen, currently a third year high school student; and Rochelle, nine, is also studying and she is now a grade three student. Their family lives in the village of Minallo, Naguilian, Isabela. Amelia has been involved in a hog raising business for three years already. Aside from this, she is also engaged in the retailing of rice, fruits and vegetables in their village, which is her daily source of income. She wants to further expand her business and she needs additional working capital to do so.

She hopes that lenders will again give her the chance to maintain and expand her business. She hopes to obtain a loan amounting to PHP 10,000 for the development of her livestock and retail business.

loans.use: Buy more livestock feed and farm supplies

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama is 29 years old. She is divorced and is the mother of four children, all of whom are currently in school.

Ama enjoys selling goods, the business from which she makes a living. She has been selling tubers of yam for six years now to support her family. She treks to farming communities to buy her stock of yams from the farmers. This saves her from intermediaries who buy from the farmers and resell to her at a higher price.

Ama wants to use the loan to buy yams in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers as we approach the Christmas festivities. She hopes to use part of her profit to support her kids in school and to expand business to the desired level. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy yams in bulk

loans.name: Calidez Group

texts.es:
El grupo Calidez está integrado por Olga María S., Alicia L. S. y Magali Nohemí G. L..  La señora S. inicio vendiendo dulces como caramelos y chiverías ahora tiene una modesta venta.

Alicia L. S. vende sopas y nacatamales los fines de semana y Magali G. vende leña. Este grupo lleva cinco ciclos con Adim en los cuales han ido prosperando y esperan seguir adelante
texts.en:
The group Calidez is make up of Olga María S., Alicia L. S. and Magali Nohemí G. L.. Señora S. began selling sweets like caramels and sweets, and now she has a small shop. Alicia L. S. sells soup and nacatamales (steamed corncakes) on the weekends, and Magali Gonzalas sells firewood. This group has done five loans with ADIM, in which they have prospered, and they hope to continue on.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy business supplies

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Group

texts.en: The Mujeres Unidas Committee uses their loan to purchase clothing, beverages, meats, sausages, breads, herb, oil, sweets, vegetables, fruits, baked goods, confectionery, dairy, haberdashery, sewing items, yarns, fabrics, scissors, clothes, vegetables, fruit, and cleaning supplies.

loans.use: Merchandise

loans.name: Anselmo

texts.en:
Anselmo B. is from the village of NHA, Cagayan de Oro City. He is 46 years old. Anselmo is married and has 4 children. To make a living, Anselmo owns & operates a business in the retail and service sector. His main source for generating revenue is managing a carenderia / food stall and at the same time runs a boarding house for rent in the local community. Anselmo has been running his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 20000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Anselmo joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and enable himself to engage in business activities. Anselmo is requesting a new loan of 30000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Anselmo from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the borrower's business.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

location.town: NHA, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Lyndie

texts.en:
Lyndie D. is from the village of Sinonoc, Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Lyndie is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Lyndie owns and operates a business raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for sale. Lyndie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lyndie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lyndie is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional feed. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Lyndie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her general living conditions.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional livestock feed

loans.name: Ivan Marcelino

texts.es:
Nuestro socio es el señor IVAN, el pertenece al banco comunal “MUJERES UNIDAS”, el socio es  natural de la ciudad del Cusco.

Nuestro socio tiene 25 años de edad es soltero, y tiene muchas ganas de salir adelante, el socio desde muy temprana edad empezó a trabajar, el era cobrador (boletero) de combis y el trabajo arduo le dio la oportunidad de ahorrar un capital de trabajo para comprar su propia combi de segunda mano y es así que el mismo empezó a conducirla y sacando todos sus papeles en regla se dedicó al transporte local en servicio de la sociedad, nuestro socio ahora solicita el préstamo para el mantenimiento de sus carro y comprar aceite y estas cosas que le permitirán mantener su carrito en optimas condiciones. 

El socio  agradece y expresa su satisfacción de poder seguir creciendo con su negocio propio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago  de su deuda en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Señor Ivan belongs to the communal bank “Women United”, he lives in the city of Cusco. He is 25 and single, and very eager to get ahead. He started working at a very young age as a ticket collector on a mini-bus, and hard work gave him the opportunity to accumulate working capital to buy his own second-hand mini-bus. He started driving it, taking care of all the paperwork properly, becoming a provider of local transport. He is requesting a loan for the maintenance of his vehicle, to buy oil and those things that will enable him to keep his van in the best condition. He expresses his gratitude and satisfaction to be able to grow his own business, and he commits himself to make the payments on the agreed schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Susan Sanford, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase supplies for the maintenance of his commercial vehicle

loans.name: Alan

texts.en:
Alan wants to provide his family with food to eat, clothes to wear and their other needs. He has been married to his wife, Evelyn, for fourteen years and they now have five children. He is determined to send all his children to school and give them a proper education. He wants all of them to finish college someday.

Alan is a rice farmer in Agusan Del Sur. He also grows chickens to add income to his household. He hopes to expand his rice field so he would have a greater harvest so he applied for a loan of Php 12,000 from CEVI. He said that he would use it to buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies he needs. He will also buy feed for his chickens.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer and other farm supplies plus feed for his chickens

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en:
Maricel L. is from the village of Tabo-o, Jimenez, Misamis Occidental. She is 29 years old. Maricel is married and has 2 school-aged children. Maricel owns & operates a service-based business, providing motorcycle "habal-habal" services to local community members. Maricel has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 2,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Maricel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Maricel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. This previous loan was used to provide additional capital for her business. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Maricel from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide service

loans.name: Genalyn's Group

texts.en:
Genalyn S. is from the village of Maluno Sur. She is the leader of a 13-member group loan offered by Kiva partner, ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Genalyn S..
Genalyn is 22 years old, married, and has one infant-aged child. To make a living, Genalyn owns and operates a service-based business. The main source of income for the business comes from providing transportation services in the local community. Genalyn has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,500 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Genalyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Genalyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Genalyn is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will also be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be her second from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Produce and sell cassava flour

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy stocks for inventory in bulk

loans.name: Massajja A Naluule Annet Group

texts.en: N. Annet is a hardworking businesswoman who is thirty-four years old and married with five children in school. She has a poultry business and has been operating the business for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase poultry items such as drugs, feed, chicks, and so forth. She is a hardworking businesswoman whose dream is to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase poultry items such as drugs, feed, chicks, and so forth

loans.name: Shamsiyya

texts.en:
Shamsiyya Q. is a 38-year-old woman who works as a cosmetologist and hairdresser in a small saloon in Saatli, Azerbaijan. She started working in 2006 when her husband lost his job.

Shamsiyya is married and has three children. Her business was the only financial source for the last four years and it was only several month ago that her husband found a job.

But Shamsiyya is going to increase her income by doing make-up for brides. She applied for 900 AZN to purchase make-up tools and cosmetics.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and make-up tools

loans.name: Mona

texts.en: Mona is a 37-year-old woman and the mother of four children. Since 1994 she has produced thyme, olives and olive oil, dry yogurt for Lebanese pizzas, lentils and pickles. Mona requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to improve her business and to purchase merchandise. This is her second loan having repaid the first on time. She offers good quality and very tasty products. Her clients are people from her region — mainly her friends, neighbors and occasionally tourists. Mona decided on her business because she is a very good cook and has experience. She says that she has a talent for cooking and loves her work. She plans to keep on improving her business as well as her financial situation.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Douglas Antonio

texts.es:
El señor Douglas Antonio R. R., tiene 36 años con su esposa y familia de 2 hijos habitan en el Barrio José Dolores Estrada, sus hijos actualmente estudian la escuela primaria, su esposa se dedica a los trabajos de casa, y él labora en una carpintería desde hace 7 años.

Inicio como aprendiz de carpintería y con el apoyo de su familia compro los utensilios básicos de un pequeño taller, a futuro espera tener los recursos necesarios para comprar un mayor inventario de herramientas que favorezcan en  los trabajos de ebanistería, él solicita un préstamo para la compra de madera y almacenarla  para la temporada de invierno debido a que por la humedad cuesta que seque y es por esta razón que prefiere tenerla disponible en inventario. Este préstamo le brindara los recursos necesarios para mejorar su capital de trabajo y recursos necesarios para mejorar sus niveles de vida.
texts.en:
Sr. Douglas Antonio R. R. is 36 years old and lives with his wife and two children in the neighborhood of José Dolores Estrada. His children currently attend elementary school while his wife takes care of the housework. Douglas has worked as a carpenter for seven years.

When he started his carpentry apprenticeship, Douglas had the support of his family and bought basic tools to establish a small workshop. In the future, he hopes to have the necessary resources to purchase a large inventory of tools used for making cabinets. He is requesting a loan in order to buy wood to store for the winter season. Since the humidity makes it difficult to find dry wood, he would prefer to keep it in stock. This loan provides him the necessary resources to increase his working capital and improve his living standards.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase wood

loans.name: Ethe

texts.en:
Ethe R. is from the village of  Tambacan Iligan City. He is 40 years old. Ethe is married and has 2 infant-aged children. To make a living, Ethe owns and operates a service-based business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing motorcycle services to local community members. Ethe has been engaged in his business for over 1 year and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Ethe joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ethe is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase materials needed to provide service. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Ethe from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase materials needed to provide transportation services

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is married with five children and all her children go to school.  She also takes care of her brother’s son. 

She is a mushroom grower in Kisaasi and sells mushrooms to all the supermarkets in Kisaasi and some in Kampala city. She wants this loan to buy more millet and seeds for mushroom growing. She has been in this mushroom growing business for three years. Betty sells to all categories of people, both retail and wholesale. 

Besides this business she also owns rental rooms. She works six days a week. Her business challenges include transportation and defaulters.  She wants to start exporting her mushrooms to other African countries. 

Betty joined MCDT because she wanted additional capital and because of their low interest rates compared to other MFI’s.  She owns and lives in a three-room house and the family has access to electricity and piped water. Her monthly expenses include food, medication and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more millet and mushroom seeds

loans.name: Terbish

texts.en:
Terbish D. is 61 years old and lives with her husband and son in Ulaanbaatar, the capital of Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, a traditional housing tent. Her son operates a second-hand car sales business while her husband is retired but helps with her business. 

Terbish runs a stall and sells a variety of clothing and consumer goods at Norjin, one of the biggest markets in Ulaanbaatar city. In 2008, she began her business and after several years of stable earnings, she used her savings to expand her business. 

Terbish is a very hardworking and decent person who manages her business as neatly as her bookkeeping. Her daily revenue reaches to 30,000 to 50,000 Mongolian tugriks (MNT) on average. She is very focused on making her business successful as it is the only source of income for her family. She is requesting a 4,000,000 MNT loan to purchase different clothes so she can expand her product line.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Suleiman

texts.en:
Suleiman is a married man with two children who attend school. He has been operating his motorcycle repair business for the last two years tomotorcycle operators and sells parts in his shop .With the Kshs 20,000 he wants to purchase spare parts for repair and pay for his business license. He has no other source of income. 

Suleiman faces the major challenge of high costs of spare parts. His major goals is to be self reliant and own a big garage in future. He decided to work with Yehu to get a loan to improve his business. He lives at a rental house with electricity but no piped water. He says food is his greatest monthly expense.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for motorcycle repairs and pay for his business license.

loans.name: Awa

texts.fr: Madame Awa N. est âgée de 27 ans et habite dans la localité de Dalifort. Elle est mariée sans enfant. Elle est femme de ménage de profession. Mais parallèlement elle a choisi l’activité de commerce par amour. Ainsi  elle achète des tissus Thioup qu’elle place auprès  de ses voisins. Madame N. est membre de la caisse de Dalifort depuis 2 ans. Elle sollicite un crédit de 400 000 frs et envisage de renforcer son stock de thioup dans le but de faire face à la demande de la clientèle en cette  période de préparation des fêtes de Korite et de tabaski. Son intention est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge des besoins de la famille.
texts.en:
Madame Awa N. is 27 years old and lives in Dalifort. She is a cleaning lady, but also runs her own business alongside this. She purchases Thioup fabric which she then sells to her neighbours. She has been a member of the Dalifort credit association for 2 years and is seeking a 400,000 FRS loan in order to boost her stock levels so that she can meet increased customer demand in this high season (in preparation for the Korite and Tabaski festivals). Her aim is to support her husband in meeting her family's needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: increasing business funds

loans.name: Abduhalim

texts.en:
M. Abduhalim is 31 years old, married and has three children. He is a farmer growing onions, corn, rice, and nuts--something he has done for 11 years. This is the only thing he knows how to do and what he likes most to do. For Abduhalim, there is nothing better than being in touch with nature and watching the crops he has planted grow year after year.

 In addition, Abduhalim raises cattle and his family helps him with his business. Now he wants to borrow money to purchase seeds and fertilizer for his crops. This is the second loan of Abduhalim from IMON International and he promises to repay the loan without any violations as he did with his previous loan. 

 
More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Mujeres De Yguazú Group

texts.es:
El comité se denomina Mujeres de Yguazú, están en el Quinto Ciclo, cuenta con 14  integrantes. Es un grupo que se destaca  en el barrio por ser muy unido, solidario y responsable, a la vez realizan actividades varias para recaudar fondos para casos de necesidad. Las integrantes poseen un gran espíritu emprendedor, ya que están al día con las cuotas y pretenden terminar esta etapa nuevamente con muy buen cumplimiento de responsabilidad con la institución. Al adquirir el crédito se les abren muchas puertas para el progreso de sus emprendimientos ya que les facilita la realización de los emprendimientos que ellas desean hacer.
La Sra. Teresa es la delegada del grupo, posee una heladería, la cual está muy bien ubicada y posee una buena clientela, además de helados comercializa golosinas.
La señora desea incrementar sus ingresos, invirtiendo en la compra de más variedades de helados, así como golosinas, teniendo en cuenta el inicio de temporada primavera-verano, lo cual ampliará la demanda de sus productos teniendo en cuenta el clima que se mantiene en el país en esta temporada.
texts.en:
This group, which is called Mujeres de Yguazú (Women of Yguazú) consists of 14 members and is in its fifth loan cycle. It is a group that stands out in the neighborhood for being very united. mutually supportive, and responsible. At the same time, they have various business activities to obtain income  for their families needs. The members have a great entrepreneurial spirit, since they are up to date with their payments and they will try to finish this new loan cycle with complete fulfillment of responsibility to the lending institution. Acquiring the loan opened many doors for them for the progress of their businesses, since it facilitated the realization of the businesses that they wanted to have.

Sra. Teresa is the representative of the group. She has an ice cream shop that is very well located and has a good clientele. In addition to ice cream, she also sells sweets. She wants to increase her income by investing in the purchase of more varieties of ice cream as well as sweets, since it is the beginning of the spring and summer season, which will increase the demand for her products because of the climate in the country in these seasons.

loans.use: Buy ice cream in quantity for resale.

loans.name: Ezekiel Lesinko

texts.en:
Ezekiel Lesinko K. is 33 years old and married to Ether K.. He supports six people in his family. Ezekiel has been farming for the last six years. His farm is in a productive area which has proved to be good for wheat farming.

Ezekiel learned about KADET LTD through a marketing campaign done by KADET staff in his area of residence. This will be his second loan, which he is planning to use to buy pesticides to spray on the growing wheat to prevent it from being invaded by pests. He hopes to use the profit from this loan to acquire more land for farming to meet the demand for wheat. His hope and dream is to become a large scale farmer and have his own farm machinery. He is a hardworking man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and pesticides for his growing wheat

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a member of the Communal Bank "Santiago the Patron Saint", located in the district of Santiago D. Pupuja, in the province of Azángaro, and the department of Puno. She is 64 years old, married, and has ten grown children. She studied until the second year of her secondary education.

Flora has worked with Manuela Ramos for two years. Her first loan was for the amount of 500 PEN, and she used the money to increase the capital for her business of selling small animals. 

She is now asking for a loan of 500 PEN, which she will use to invest in her business. Her dream is to improve the area in which she keeps her animals.

Flora's favorite things about working with the Communal Bank are the training and the meetings, because she likes the conversations between the bank members.

loans.use: Invest in her business selling small animals.

loans.name: Wendy Patricia

texts.es:
En la ciudadela La California de  Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Rio De Oro.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Wendy, ella tiene 42 años de edad, esta casada y fruto de esta relación ha procreado cuatro hijos, tres de ellos son mayores de edad, con ella vive su hijo menor y dos nietos que son como sus hijos. Su hijo estudia en colegio. Su esposo es profesor de un colegio de la ciudad.

Se dedica al comercio, vende ropa interior de todo tipo, medias y otros artículos, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta, ofrece sus productos a sus amigas  y vecinas, trabaja todos los días desde las 8 hasta las 10h30 y desde las 15h00 hasta las 18h00. Dice que tiene varios clientes que le piden sus productos porque algunos de ellos son importados. Ella compra en Guayaquil cada fin de mes y también le envían desde los Estados Unidos sobre todo la ropa intima de mujer. 

Este crédito es para pagar el pedido que realizo a la señora que le envía de los Estados Unidos. Esta en el Banco Comunal hace tres años y le gusta porque los intereses son sumamente bajos. Su sueño es tener su propio local donde vender sus productos.
texts.en:
In the town of La California de Portoviejo, capital of Manabí and known for many years as the city of the regal tamarind, the members of the Rio de Oro cooperative bank reunite every fifteen days.

Here we find Wendy, who is 42 years old, married, and has four children.  Three of her kids are grown, and her youngest son and two grandchildren, who are like her own kids, live with her.  Her son is in school.  Her husband is a teacher at one of the city’s schools.

She dedicates herself to commerce, selling all types of undergarments, socks, and other items.  She sells door-to-door, offering her products to her friends and neighbors.  She works every day from 8 am until 10:30 am, and from 5 pm until 8 pm.  She tells us she has various customers that request her products because some of them are imported.  She makes her purchases in Guayaquil at the end of each month, and also orders some from the United States, especially women’s lingerie.

This loan is to pay for an order she placed with the woman who sends her items from the United States.  She has been in the cooperative bank for three years, and is very content because the interest rates are extremely low.  Her dream is to have her own store where she could sell her products.

loans.use: To purchase women's undergarments.

loans.name: Rober

texts.es: Rober, de 32 años, está casado con Janeth, de 31 años. Ambos tienen 3 hijos: Anderson, de 10, Sharon, de 8 y Paúl, de 5 años. En unión familiar viven en su casa propia; ubicada en la localidad de San Pedro de Cajas. El trabajo al que se dedica son las construcciones de casas, en las cuales también realiza el servicio de instalación de agua y tuberías. Pero la actividad que más, le gusta a Rober es la artesanía; desde que era joven se dedica al tejido de mantas, tapices, ponchos de lana. A los que gracias a su buen tejido y creatividad puede comercializarlo a los intermediarios que visitan constantemente el lugar, los que venden sus productos en diferentes lugares del país. Pero su mayor anhelo es tener un negocio que le de mayor rentabilidad, es por ello que más adelante piensa comprar un terreno, donde construirá su casa propia y pueda acondicionar un negocio de venta de comida. Es el primer crédito con MFP y, como un nuevo integrante de su banco comunal, se compromete a pagar puntualmente sus cuotas. Con el crédito que obtendrá, le servirá para comprar 15 bolsas de carretes de hilos para tejer, ya que tiene un costo de S/. 120.00 soles cada una.
texts.en:
Rober, 32, is married to Janeth, 31, and they have three kids together: Anderson, 10; Sharon, 8; and Paúl, 5.  They live in their own house in the town of San Pedro de Cajas.  He works in home construction, and also installs pipes and water services.  But what Rober likes best is hand-crafts; ever since he was young he has made hand-woven wool blankets, rugs, and ponchos.  

Thanks to his quality weaving and his creativity he can market to middle-men who visit him all the time and sell his products around the country.  But Rober's biggest dream is to have a more profitable business, so he's thinking that down the line he'll buy some land where he can build his own house and put in a food-sales business.

This will be Rober's first loan with MFP, and, as a new member of his village bank, he promises to make his payments on time.  He plans to use his loan to buy 15 bags of spools of thread for weaving, since they cost 120 soles each.

loans.use: To buy 15 bags of spools of thread.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “SR. DE TAYANCANI”;  El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Ocongate perteneciente a la provincia de Quispicanchis y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Antonia; La socia tiene 2 hijos ella se dedica al comercio minorista, la socia trabaja criando animales menores, ella compra cuyes al por mayor, también tiene chanchos y aves de corral (gallinas, pollos, gallos), las gallina sle dan huevos a diario y los pollos cuando alcanza la madurez los vende a otros compradores, las gallinas también en su debido tiempo y los gallos para reproducción, la socia realiza todo un negocio con la venta de estos animales y al momento de reproducirse ella los va vendiendo también, la socia hace lo mismo con los cuyes; La socia tuvo una perdida con sus cuyes por el mal clima se enfermaron y murieron, ahora después de recuperarse y de limpiar las jaulas y el espacio está dispuesta a comenzar de nuevo. La socia invertirá el dinero en la compra de cuyes, para comenzar una nueva camada y de este modo incrementar sus ventas y su economía.  La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de animales menores (cuyes).

La socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y del mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de su cuota en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
Mrs. Antonia belongs to the Sr. de Tayacani Community Bank. This bank is located in the district of Ocongate, province of Quispichachis, department of Cusco.

She has two children who work retailing goods, and she works raising animals for sale. She buys guinea pigs wholesale, and she also owns pigs, hens, chickens, and roosters. Her hens provide her with eggs every day, and when the chickens are fully grown she sells them to various buyers. She also sells hens and roosters for reproduction. She has a full enterprise with selling these animals and their offspring. She has done the same selling guinea pigs; however she suffered a setback when her guinea pigs got sick and died dude to inclement weather. Now after some time to recover and clean out her cages she is ready to begin raising guinea pigs again. She will use the loan to purchase guinea pigs and start a new litter; this way she can improve her sales and her income. 

Mrs. Antonia is grateful for the loan made available through this medium, and she pledges to make her payments on time.

loans.use: Purchase of young guinea pigs.

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is married with two adult sons. She rents space at a small store where she sells clothing. Olga started her business 15 years ago and has been developing and improving it since then. Olga enjoys her business and would like to further expand. 

Olga is requesting a loan of 15,000 UAH to increase the assortment of her inventory. She has used business loans before and found them very helpful. Olga hopes to increase her sales to make additional profit.

loans.use: to purchase inventory

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en: This Kiva borrower is a 34-year-old married man living with his wife and two young children who are attending school. He worked as a metal specialist for more than 18 years and in 2000, he bought an iron-cutting machine and started to do his own design work. He obtained his first Kiva loan and he was an excellent client. He is very satisfied with the results and he is requesting to borrow $2,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to complete the needed maintenance for his machinery. This will allow him to continue his work, which represents his family's only income source.

loans.use: To complete the needed maintenance for his machinery

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
Susan L. is from the village of Talisayan, Misamis Oriental. She is 27 years old. Susan is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Susan owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, canned goods, snack foods, biscuits and toothpaste in the local community. Susan has been engaged in her business for more than two years and earns approximately 14,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Susan joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. Susan has successfully repaid a previous loan of 21,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional inventory and for working capital. 

Susan is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell, like snack foods, instant noodles and canned goods. This will be the sixth loan taken by Susan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Lim

texts.en:
Lim Y., age 28, is pictured here with her husband at their house. To earn a living, Lim Y. cultivates a rice crop. This couple has two kids who study at the local school. She has a life partner in her husband who is a domestic laborer, earning a profit of approximately $4.50 per day. 

In the past, Lim Y. mortgaged her farmland in order to treat her mother's illness. Now she wants to pay back the money so it will belong to her again, but her personal savings is not enough to do that. To solve this problem, Lim Y. has decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings in order to redeem the mortgage on her farm.

loans.use: To redeem a mortgage on a farm.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen J. is from the village of Dalirig, Manolo Fortich, Bukidnon. She is 50 years old, married and has 4 school-aged children. Helen owns and operates a specialized retail store, buying and selling dried fish and squid in the local community. Helen has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 6,000 PHP a month from it.

In 2011, Helen joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Helen is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional dried fish to sell. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Helen from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional dried fish to sell

loans.name: Lenie

texts.en:
Lenie B. is from the village of Malibago, Oro. She is 43 years old, married, and has six school-aged children.
